texts.orig: Sending signals to processes using  kill  on a Unix system is not a new topic for most systems administrators, but I've been asked many times about the difference between
texts.text: Sending signals to processes using  kill  on a Unix system is not a new topic for most systems administrators, but I've been asked many times about the difference between

texts.label: text
texts.orig: on a process, you're actually sending the process a signal (in almost all situations – I'll get into that soon). Standard C applications have a  header file  that contains the steps that the process should follow if it receives a particular signal. You can get an entire list of the available signals on your system by checking the man page for
texts.text: on a process, you're actually sending the process a signal (in almost all situations – I'll get into that soon). Standard C applications have a  header file  that contains the steps that the process should follow if it receives a particular signal. You can get an entire list of the available signals on your system by checking the man page for

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This would send a signal called  SIGTERM  to the process. Once the process receives the notice, a few different things can happen:
texts.text: This would send a signal called  SIGTERM  to the process. Once the process receives the notice, a few different things can happen:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: the process may stop after a short delay after cleaning up resources
texts.text: the process may stop after a short delay after cleaning up resources

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: the process may keep running indefinitely
texts.text: the process may keep running indefinitely

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The application can determine what it wants to do once a SIGTERM is received. While most applications will clean up their resources and stop, some may not. An application may be configured to do something completely different when a SIGTERM is received. Also, if the application is in a bad state, such as waiting for disk I/O, it may not be able to act on the signal that was sent.
texts.text: The application can determine what it wants to do once a SIGTERM is received. While most applications will clean up their resources and stop, some may not. An application may be configured to do something completely different when a SIGTERM is received. Also, if the application is in a bad state, such as waiting for disk I/O, it may not be able to act on the signal that was sent.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Most system administrators will usually resort to the more abrupt signal when an application doesn't respond to a SIGTERM:
texts.text: Most system administrators will usually resort to the more abrupt signal when an application doesn't respond to a SIGTERM:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: command that you want to send signal #9, which is called  SIGKILL . With a name like that, it's obvious that this signal carries a little more weight.
texts.text: command that you want to send signal #9, which is called  SIGKILL . With a name like that, it's obvious that this signal carries a little more weight.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Although SIGKILL is defined in the same signal header file as SIGTERM, it cannot be ignored by the process. In fact, the process isn't even made aware of the SIGKILL signal since the signal goes straight to  the kernel  init. At that point, init will stop the process. The process never gets the opportunity to catch the signal and act on it.
texts.text: Although SIGKILL is defined in the same signal header file as SIGTERM, it cannot be ignored by the process. In fact, the process isn't even made aware of the SIGKILL signal since the signal goes straight to  the kernel  init. At that point, init will stop the process. The process never gets the opportunity to catch the signal and act on it.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: However, the kernel may not be able to successfully kill the process in some situations. If the process is waiting for network or disk I/O, the kernel won't be able to stop it.  Zombie processes  and processes caught in an  uninterruptible sleep  cannot be stopped by the kernel, either. A reboot is required to clear those processes from the system.
texts.text: However, the kernel may not be able to successfully kill the process in some situations. If the process is waiting for network or disk I/O, the kernel won't be able to stop it.  Zombie processes  and processes caught in an  uninterruptible sleep  cannot be stopped by the kernel, either. A reboot is required to clear those processes from the system.
